greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: For n=0,1,2,... list all products of the first n primes raised to some positive power not exceeding n.
comment: Alternate construction: For n=0,1,2,... write all strings of length n using the first n symbols of the alphabet (""; a; aa,ab,ba,bb; aaa,aab,aac, aba,...), then code / interpret them as "positional" notation of exponents (a=1, b=2, ...) of primes (last digit = least prime), e.g.: acb => [1,3,2] => 5^1 3^3 2^2.
These numbers have the property that, if a prime p divides the number, then all primes less than p also divide it. (But not all such numbers are listed, neither are they listed in increasing order.)
example: The sequence begins: a(1)=1 (empty product); a(2)=2^1;
They correspond to the strings (cf. comment) "" a aa ab ba bb aaa aab aac aba abb abc aca acb acc baa bab bac ...
program: (PARI) for( L=0,3, forvec( v=vector(L,i,[1,L]), print1( prod( j=1,L,prime(j)^v[L-j+1] )",")))
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, May 31 2010
